The following are the recommended harvest and postharvest practices for tomato.

  • Harvest tomato fruit from 55-60 days after transplanting (DAT) depending upon the maturity of the variety. It may also depend on the intended use of the fruit. 

  • Use the fruit’s color as the harvest index to determine the proper time of harvesting tomato fruits. Both mature green and ripe can be harvested for table tomato. Ripe fruits are for immediate consumption while green mature fruits are for transport.

  • Harvest fruits at green mature stage to avoid fruit cracking when rain is continuous whereas harvest at breaker (half ripe) stage during periods of interspersed dry spells.

  • Harvest the fruits preferably when dry. If the prevailing condition does not allow, wipe the harvested fruits with a piece of cloth.

  • Sort ripe from unripe fruits to slow down ripening as ripe fruits emit ethylene that enhances fruit ripening when harvesting.
